name: NPR
text:
Gwinnett County Public Schools — Georgia’s largest school district — will move online this fall, reversing its previous plan to hold a mix of in-person and online classes.
https://t.co/foxHxbL6a1

name: NPR
text: Tesla turned a profit for the fourth straight quarter, making it eligible to join the S&P 500 stock index — and become part of the retirement accounts of millions of Americans. https://t.co/0VAd6elrBn

name: NPR
text:
The U.S. ambassador to the U.K. told embassy staff in 2018 that his friend, President Trump, asked him to help get the British Open golf tournament held at a Trump golf resort in Scotland.
https://t.co/iUlKFmUltn

name: NPR
text:
Idaho’s coronavirus cases are rising exponentially, and about half of the more than 15,000 confirmed cases have come in the past two weeks.

"If we do not reverse this trend, we are headed for a crisis," says one hospital official. 
https://t.co/SHaztfT9pT

name: NPR
text:
Because of the pandemic, sports fans won't be in the stands this season. Instead, Major League Baseball is planning to pump recorded sounds of crowds into empty ballparks during games.
https://t.co/9fTldezFdR

name: NPR
text: The U.K. will no longer offer immunity to the family of U.S. staff at a military base where a diplomat's wife fled the country after allegedly killing a teenager with her car. https://t.co/IYYDuAG2jp

name: NPR
text:
The elderly and people with disabilities are already some of the most at-risk during natural disasters.

Amid an ongoing pandemic, officials across the South are scrambling to adjust their evacuation and shelter plans.  https://t.co/ODvQ2UrPKn

name: NPR
text:
The Florida Fish and Wildlife Conservation Commission approved a five-year ban on harvesting wild oysters from Apalachicola Bay to give the fishery time to recover.

Some oystermen worry closing the bay will be a final devastating blow.
https://t.co/HS428SOdhn

name: NPR
text:
President Trump says he will deploy federal agents to Chicago and Albuquerque, N.M., to fight what he says are "heinous crimes," adding that the administration has "no choice but to get involved."
https://t.co/AiuTEvTffh

name: NPR
text: An Arab-Muslim entrepreneur is facing a backlash and fighting to keep his once-burgeoning business alive after his daughter's racist and anti-LGBTQ social media posts became public. https://t.co/MjcO9hsSio

name: NPR
text: In 2018 Andrew Delke, a white Nashville police officer, shot Daniel Hambrick, a Black man, while he was running away with a gun. For the first time in the city's history, an officer was charged with murder. @WPLN's Deadly Force podcast digs into the case. https://t.co/3WLy6hs7UK

name: NPR
text: Nicholson Baker's "Baseless" misses the mark in an aim to take readers on a quest to discover if the U.S. used biological weapons developed in the '50s — and to examine the failings of public records law. https://t.co/YppyTPi8kK

name: NPR
text:
With peak hurricane season yet to come, southeast communities are grappling with whether it's possible to evacuate to shelters without risking coronavirus exposure.

"I'd stay outside before I'd go up in that school," says one Hurricane Katrina survivor.
https://t.co/HdjbxkGaKn

name: NPR
text:
The Seattle City Council supports a 50% cut to the police budget — a move the police chief says would be "reckless" right now.

“I'm hoping that people will calm down and look at ways that we can have a real plan in place," she says.
https://t.co/mxB7JSTd2u

name: NPR
text: After a 25-year hiatus, Joshua Redman, Brad Mehldau, @jazznight host Christian McBride and Brian Blade reunite for a concert video — plus a Q&A about their new studio album.  https://t.co/qcyzUCqFi4

name: NPR
text: Anne Applebaum writes in "Twilight of Democracy" that heir to fears and hatreds, even advanced societies are straining under repeated blows: protracted war, economic disruptions, migration, a pandemic. https://t.co/zFFDfOJqHy

name: NPR
text:
🎸🎶 Listen to @niluferyanya debut a new track — and perform 3 works from her last album — in a special Tiny Desk (home) concert.
https://t.co/U7slYdEr3j

name: NPR
text: A college student's bill for outpatient knee surgery was a whopper — $96,377 — but the kicker was a $1,167 charge from a surgical assistant she didn't recall meeting or being told would be involved in her case. https://t.co/Jv3Pdq85oK

name: NPR
text:
In 2019, Gail Shepherd published a novel about a white girl growing up in the South. But in the original draft, the main character wasn’t white; she was Vietnamese American.

@HiddenBrain examines where to draw the line between empathy and appropriation. https://t.co/tylGJseuAm

name: NPR
text:
Kim Yo Jong has risen steadily in North Korean politics since her brother Kim Jong Un took power in 2011 — leading to speculation that she could one day become the country's first female leader.

But analysts say a patriarchal system makes that unlikely.
 https://t.co/ykdgtHwP4z

name: NPR
text:
Shot over 15 years, a new documentary catalogs the rise of Lin-Manuel Miranda, Christopher Jackson and other members of the hip-hop group Freestyle Love Supreme before they became famous on Broadway.
 https://t.co/xKvx2pbbEx

name: NPR
text:
Set in a Dublin maternity ward in 1918, Emma Donoghue's novel "The Pull of the Stars" dives into the past, capturing a city devastated by a pandemic, while presciently anticipating our present miseries.
https://t.co/ecvwI166nU

name: NPR
text:
Derek Chauvin, the former police officer charged in the murder of George Floyd, has also been charged with his wife with 9 counts of felony tax evasion.

Authorities say they underreported their joint income from 2014-2019 by $464,433.
https://t.co/Fp8fdYebEA

name: NPR
text:
New claims for unemployment benefits rose to 1.4 million last week — the first increase since March.
https://t.co/eefpln9bIg

name: NPR
text:
Tommy Rhine has owned a shoe repair shop for decades. But it was hit hard by the pandemic, and he fell behind in rent. Then his son put up a "Black owned business" sign.

Now, he's taking orders from states away—and has raised tens of thousands of dollars.
https://t.co/Khj45S8gHI

name: NPR
text:
GOP senators and the White House have reached an agreement in principle on a major portion of an upcoming coronavirus aid bill.

The agreement, which includes $105 billion for schools, is meant to be a starting point for bipartisan talks on a final bill.
https://t.co/AHj1YfsiEZ

name: NPR
text:
FEMA is urging emergency managers to consider using vacant hotel rooms to house evacuees this hurricane season. 

But few towns have them lined up in the South, where coronavirus infections are raging.
https://t.co/YLSWXN0gO5

name: NPR
text:
Australia's Qantas Airways has retired its last Boeing 747. For the plane's final flight, pilots sketched out a giant kangaroo logo with its flight path off the east coast of Australia.
https://t.co/QyOngaXiI7

name: NPR
text:
China has launched an ambitious project to send an orbiter, lander and rover to Mars. If everything goes according to plan, it will be China's first successful mission to the red planet, after a failed attempt in 2011.
https://t.co/FAlPkZO6Er

name: NPR
text:
A growing number of parents around the country are filing lawsuits that question whether schools and education departments have addressed the needs of special education students during the pandemic.
https://t.co/8d36hBpsRm

name: NPR
text: RT @nprpolitics: NEW: A federal judge has ordered President Trump's former personal lawyer Michael Cohen to be released from prison, finding that the government's decision to return Cohen to prison after his initial coronavirus-related release was retaliation for his plans to write a book.NEW: A federal judge has ordered President Trump's former personal lawyer Michael Cohen to be released from prison,… https://t.co/fRxmoZXSrQ

name: NPR
text:
Given the choice between a person and another animal, this type of mosquito prefers to drink human blood.

A new study explains how that came to be, in part because of how people store water — which mosquitoes need for laying eggs — in hot, dry climates.
https://t.co/MKii7a6DfB

name: NPR
text: Shortly after Portland Mayor Ted Wheeler left a protest where federal agents had tear-gassed him, the city's police "declared the event a riot" and ordered people to either disperse or face repercussions — including arrest or the possible use of tear gas. https://t.co/ePkPSc7LT0

name: NPR
text:
Major League Baseball's shortened season begins Thursday night, with Dr. Anthony Fauci slated to throw out the first pitch in Washington. But can baseball finish its 60-game sprint while avoiding a coronavirus outbreak?
https://t.co/qsrFpLUVon

name: NPR
text:
The parent company of Ann Taylor, Loft, Lane Bryant and several other clothing brands is filing for bankruptcy amid the coronavirus crisis. The group has not specified how many locations it'll close.
https://t.co/uRsxcpL6dz

name: NPR
text:
RT @Roughly: Venezuelans trapped in Ecuador by COVID-19 are determined to make the 1000+ mile trip back, on foot if they have to. The story of their return, and the 53 year-old civil servant leading one group home. 

New episode with @elhilopodcast + @radioambulante. 
https://t.co/JfD6iqPSzV

name: NPR
text:
After GOP Rep. Ted Yoho was overheard referring to Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez as "disgusting" and a "f***ing bitch," Ocasio-Cortez responded on the House floor — saying her parents "did not raise me to accept abuse from men."

Watch her remarks ⤵️
https://t.co/um4AN1fgaq

name: NPR
text: A judge has ordered that Michael Cohen be released to home confinement, finding that his return to prison after his initial coronavirus-related release was retaliation for his plans to publish a tell-all about working with Trump. https://t.co/pj9wQZuafk

name: NPR
text:
The Trump administration portrays antifa as the leftist equivalent to violent hate groups on the right. 

But domestic terrorism data show far-right extremists killed at least 38 people in 2019. The death toll linked to antifa?

One — the attacker himself. https://t.co/vbreh9d4PB

name: NPR
text:
President Trump is repealing an Obama-era rule intended to combat historic racial discrimination in housing.  

Recently, Trump has referenced the rule heavily in his push to win suburban voters.
https://t.co/VK2G04Hjfc

name: NPR
text: How economics went from medieval to modern, a (kinda) musical from @planetmoney ⤵️ https://t.co/Yx0jKKZHgJ

name: NPR
text:
In her book, President Trump’s niece describes him as a "belligerent" youth who hasn't changed since he was a teen.

“He says these outrageous things that are hurtful or insulting or wildly inappropriate and people laugh it off." https://t.co/VkE0mmd1Oy

name: NPR
text:
The Border Patrol unit deployed to Portland is chiefly trained to pursue fugitives and criminals, says a former CBP commissioner.

"This is clearly an urban environment and civil unrest. It is not in their wheelhouse," he said. "I mean, they track people." https://t.co/JfKkwRKIqQ

name: NPR
text: JUST IN: President Trump says he decided to cancel the Jacksonville, Florida, portion of the Republican convention… https://t.co/LI0R10Fwcu

name: NPR
text:
RT @nprpolitics: JUST IN: President Trump said he decided to cancel the Jacksonville, Florida portion of the Republican convention in August. 

“The timing is not right” with the flare up of coronavirus cases in Florida, Trump said.JUST IN: President Trump said he decided to cancel the Jacksonville, Florida portion of the Republican convention i… https://t.co/5xsldbUTY6

name: NPR
text:
NEW: President Trump has canceled the Jacksonville component of the Republican National Convention as coronavirus cases spike across Florida.

"It's just not right with what's been happening," he said.
https://t.co/6dFJu09cjK

name: NPR
text:
Through the personal accounts of 4 people who lived during the Great Depression, @throughlineNPR looks at the lessons we can take from the last time the U.S. went through a national economic cataclysm.

Listen: https://t.co/TrlEuDIP3O https://t.co/i29moQJ4m4

name: NPR
text:
Florida reported its largest number of coronavirus deaths in a single day on Thursday: 173. 
https://t.co/XGQhyv2zxi

name: NPR
text:
The Justice Department's inspector general has opened an investigation into allegations of DOJ personnel improperly using force in Portland, Ore., as well as an inquiry into their role in responding to mass protests in D.C. 
https://t.co/0A9qrftGya

name: NPR
text:
"I learned about Operation Legend from actually someone on Twitter who had notified me that it was occurring," says Kansas City Mayor Quinton Lucas.

Some 250 federal law enforcement officers have been sent to the city.
https://t.co/xKzvcY3YMb
